questions.text: 60 year old patient presents to the OPD with pain in several joints of the hand. On examination, there is features of arthritis in PIP, DIP and 1st CMC joint. However, the wrist is spared. What is the likely diagnosis?
52 year male comes to trauma centre with 2cm wound on his left leg. His X ray shows multi fragmentary segmental fracture of left tibia and fibula. Classify his fracture.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is C. Gustilo Anderson class-3A.

The Gustilo Anderson classification is a system for classifying open fractures based on the severity of the soft tissue injury. The classification system has four grades:

  • Grade 1: Clean wound <1 cm long.
  • Grade 2: Laceration >1 but < 10 cm, however more importantly, there must not be any grade 3 features such as gross comminution or segmental fracture, gross contamination, extensive soft tissue loss or vascular injury. If any of these are present then irrespective of the size of the wound, the fracture has to be classified as grade 3
  • Grade 3A: Extensive soft tissue injury with adequate coverage of bone.
  • Grade 3B: Extensive soft tissue injury with inadequate coverage of bone that requires flap or free tissue transfer.
  • Grade 3C: Open fracture with an arterial injury that requires repair.

In this case, even though the wound is small, the fracture is comminuted, so we ignore the size of the wound and classify it as grade 3 open fracture. Again, as there is no mention of significant soft tissue loss or vascular injury in the question, we can sub classify the fracture as grade 3A

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is an IL-1 antagonist typically used as a second line agent in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
• IL-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1R) is a naturally occurring molecule that blocks the biologic effects of the pro-inflammatory cytokine
  • IL-1. A recombinant form of human IL-1R, Anakinra, is used to manage rheumatoid arthritis patients who are refractory to more conventional forms of treatment.
  • Methotrexate and leflunomide are DMARD's, and are typically prescribed if low dose corticosteroids are ineffective. Adalimumab and etanercept are both TNF-alpha blockers.

questions.text: Gunstock deformity is seen in which of the following fractures?
questions.solution:
• Most common complication in SCH fracture- malunion
  • Most common deformity occurs in SCH fracture- gun stock deformity or cubitusvarus deformity
  • Deformity managed by- French osteotomy (lateral closing wedge osteotomy)

choices.text: Retinal changes of fat or petechiae

questions.text: What is the major criteria for fat embolism?
questions.solution:
The three major factors for diagnosing fat embolism according to GURD's criteria are

  1. Respiratory symptoms
  2. Cerebral symptoms and
  3. Petechial rashes.

questions.text: Which of the following is an epiphyseal tumor?
questions.solution:
CHONDROBLASTOMA:

  • This benign tumor of immature cartilage cells is one of the few lesions to appear primarily in the epiphysis, usually of the proximal humerus, femur or tibia.
  • The presenting symptom is a constant ache in the joint; the tender spot is actually in the adjacent bone.
  • X-ray shows a rounded, well-demarcated radiolucent area in the epiphysis with no hint of central calcification.
  • Tumors according to their Origin Site in long bone

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with low back and hip pain that has been gradually worsening over the past year. He reports the symptoms are worse in the morning. Radiographs are shown in the image. Laboratory studies show a positive HLA-B27. What additional finding will help confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• MC extraarticular manifestation of AS is anterior uveitis.
  • The radiograph shows bilateral sacroiliitis. Bilateral sacroiliitis (with or without uveitis) and a postive HLA-B27 is diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by a positive HLA-B27 with a negative RF titer.
  • It typically presents between 15 to 35 years of age and is more common in men than women. Low back pain usually precedes the radiogaphic findings of bilateral sacroiliitis.
  • Option A: Erythema marginatum is a major criterion for Acute Rheumatic Fever.
  • Option B: HLA-DR3 is associated with SLE.
  • Option D: RF is found in rheumatoid arthritis, Sjogren's, sarcoid, and SLE.

questions.text: A Tennis player presents with a history of multiple episodes of spontaneous shoulder dislocation due to glenoid labrum injury. Now he states that, he can himself correct his dislocations. This condition most likely is:
questions.solution:
• Most common joint dislocation in body: Shoulder dislocation
  • MC type of shoulder dislocation: Anterior
  • Shoulder instability: Head of the humerus is NOT stable in the glenoid. It can present with:
    • Loose shoulder/minor shoulder instability: Patient present with pain in shoulder upon using it. Pain occurs as a result of stretching of capsule, as the head moves out, without actual dislocation
    • Frank dislocation: Patient presents with abnormal movement of the head of humerus → partial movement→ gets spontaneously reduced or dislocated
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • MC: Fall on outstretched hand with the shoulder abducted and externally rotated.
    • Direct force (as seen in tennis player) pushing humerus head from glenoid cavity.
  • Classification of anterior shoulder dislocation:
    • Preglenoid/ subglenoid: Head of humerus lies in front of glenoid
    • Subcoracoid: MC type; head lies below the coracoids process
    • Subclavicular: Head lies below the clavicle
    • Intrathoracic
  • Posterior shoulder dislocation is associated with epileptiform convulsion or as a consequence of electric shock.
  • LuxatioErecta - inferior dislocation. Rare type of shoulder dislocation. Head comes to lie in the subglenoid position.
  • Hill-Sachs lesion, also Hill-Sachs fracture, is a cortical depression in the posterolateral head of the humerus bone. It is seen in anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Reverse Hill Sach's lesion is due to posterior shoulder dislocation. Micro avulsion is seen on antero-medial aspect of humeral head.
  • Bankart lesion is avulsion of anterior glenoid labrum.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl comes to the office with increasing thigh pain mostly at night. Radiograph and biopsy specimen are shown in Figures A and B. The patients WBC and ESR are both elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This patient's history, radiograph and biopsy are consistent with Ewing's sarcoma. Specifically, the radiograph shows an infiltrative, non-geographic lesion with periosteal reaction and "ONION-PEEL APPEARANCE".
  • The pathology slide shows a diffuse sheet of small round blue cells lining the bone trabeculae-diagnostic of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Current treatment for Ewing's sarcoma includes neoadjuvant chemotherapy, surgical resection and adjuvant chemotherapy. Only in "unresectable" tumors or situations where resection would be associated with poor functional outcome would Ewing's be treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy without surgical excision.
  • Ewing sarcoma is the most chemo sensitive and most radiosensitive malignant bone tumor.
  • Ewing sarcoma(> osteosarcoma) is the most common tumor showing bone to bone metastasis, hence mandating a bone scan to detect the metastasis.

questions.text: Lauge Hansen classification system is used for?
questions.solution: The Lauge-Hansen classification system is used for the classification of ankle injuries based on injury mechanisms that have predictable patterns and imaging findings. Along with the Weber classification, these systems are useful tools for describing and classifying ankle injuries.

questions.text: Anterior cruciate ligaments prevent?
questions.solution:
• The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) stretches from the lateral condyle of femur to the anterior intercondylar area.
  • The ACL is critically important because it prevents the tibia from being pushed too far anterior relative to the femur. It is often torn during twisting or bending of the knee.
  • If there is ACL tear, reconstruction is most commonly done by autograft, meaning the tissue used for the repair is taken from the patient's body.
  • The two most common sources for tissue are the patellar tendon and hamstrings tendon.
  • The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) stretches from medial condyle of femur to the posterior intercondylar area. This ligament prevents posterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur

questions.text: 70 years old male, known case of chronic renal failure suffers from a pathological fracture of his right femur. What could be the underlying mechanism that has caused this?
questions.solution:
• In chronic renal failure, 3 things happen-
    1. The 1-alpha hydroxylation and activation of vitamin D fails,
    2. Persistent loss of calcium through urine and
    3. Phosphate retention.
  • When this happens, insoluble calcium phosphate forms in the body and removes calcium from the circulation. Both processes lead to hypocalcaemia.
  • Whenever there is hypocalcemia, the parathyroid gland senses it and releases PTH. This elevation of PTH in response to hypocalcemia is called secondary hyperparathyroidism. The elevated level of PTH will cause demineralization of bone, causing the ones to weaken and undergo pathological fractures. The bone damage occurring in renal failure is called renal osteodystrophy.
  • Please note that secondary hyperparathyroidism is also seen in rickets and osteomalacia and for that matter, any condition causing hypocalcemia.
  • Renal osteodystrophy.
    • Bone and joint pain are common, as are limb deformities.
    • Pathological fractures are common.
    • Diagnosis- the clinching biochemical change is elevated phosphate levels. The PTH is also elevated due to decreased levels of calcium or 1, 25-dihydroxy-vitamin D3 and there will be altered renal function tests.
    • In people with chronic renal failure, treatment consists of dietary restriction of phosphorus, supplements with an active form of vitamin D such as calcitriol, doxercalciferol, paricalcitol, etc., and phosphate binders which can be divided into calcium-based and non-calcium based.
  • But caused more issues with low blood calcium levels and vomiting.
    • Most people with hyperparathyroidism secondary to chronic kidney disease will improve after renal transplantation, but many will continue to have a degree of residual hyper parathyroidism(tertiary hyperparathyroidism) posttransplant with associated risk of bone loss, etc.,

questions.text: The spina ventosa is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Spina ventosa/Tuberculous dactylitis is a rare skeletal tuberculosis of short tubular bones like phalanges, metacarpals, metatarsals.
  • This condition is uncommon after the age of 5 years. It is also known as tuberculosis dactylitis.
  • In this condition hand is more frequently involved than foot.
  • Due to abundant blood flow through the large nutrient artery, almost in the middle of the bone, the first inoculum of infection, lodged in the center of marrow cavity, leads to spindle shaped expansion of bone called spina ventosa.
  • Caries sicca: TB shoulder
  • Poncet disease - TB associated with polyarthritis

questions.text: Inversion injury to ankle caused damage to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
• Inversion injury to ankle involves damage to talofibular ligament (the lateral complex).
  • INVERSION INJURY
    • An inversion force with the foot in plantar flexion results in the sprain of the anterior talofibular ligament of the ankle.
    • It is the most common ligament injury occurring in the body.

questions.text: Condition in which there is anterior or posterior displacement of a vertebra in relation to the vertebrae below:
questions.solution:
Spondylosis - Degenerative osteoarthritis of the joints of the spinal column.

Spondylitis - is an inflammation of the vertebra. It is usually seen in inflammatory conditions such as ankylosing spondylitis.

Spondylolysis - it is a defect or break in the pars interarticularis of the vertebra. Pars interarticularis is an important structure that links a vertebra to its adjacent vertebrae. Any defect in it can predispose the slipping of one vertebra over its lower vertebra resulting in spondylolisthesis. So, spondylolysis is the precursor of spondylolisthesis.

Spondylolisthesis - The anterior or posterior displacement of a vertebra or the vertebral column in relation to the vertebrae below it.

choices.text: It is subluxation of radial head.
It is treated by fully supinating the forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the pulled elbow?
questions.solution:
• An x-ray image is not useful as it appears normal in case of pulled elbow.
  • The pulled elbow, also called nursemaid's elbow, is the subluxation of radial head out from the annular ligament.
  • It is caused by the axial traction on the extended arm, while the forearm is pronated such as when a child is pulled at the wrist to prevent a fall or is picked up from the floor by their hand.
  • The patient comes with the forearm in the pronated position and supination is resisted. The head is reduced by fully supinating and flexing the forearm, while applying direct pressure over the radial head.

choices.text: Surgical intervention after cultures and sensitivity reports
Repeat aspiration of the knee and send for alpha-defensin
Begin IV antibiotics and re-evaluate in 24-48 hours

questions.text: A 66-year-old patient that underwent a right total knee arthroplasty approximately 4 years ago presents with worsening right knee pain over the last 48 hours. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and recently underwent a dental procedure a week ago. Labs were significant for CRP of 212, ESR 105, and a WBC count of 11000. Aspiration yielded a milky-looking fluid with 55000 nucleated cells with 97% PMN. Radiographs are shown in Figures A and B. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
• The patient is presenting with an acute hematogenous prosthetic joint infection, which requires surgical treatment as soon as safely possible.
  • Periprosthetic joint infections (PJI) are generally managed surgically.
  • Diagnosis is composed of a battery of findings as established by the Musculoskeletal Infection Society (MSIS), which requires the presence of one of two major criteria or four of six minor criteria (Illustration A).
  • Acute infections can often be treated with irrigation and debridement with polyethylene exchange (IDPE), whereas chronic infections are best managed with a two-stage revision.

Incorrect Answers:

Option A: Delaying surgical intervention for aspiration cultures to finalize is not recommended. Ideally, surgery should proceed as soon as safely possible.

Option B: Repeat aspiration and sending for alpha-defensin would further delay treatment in this patient.

Option C: IV antibiotics alone is not sufficient treatment for PJI in patients able to tolerate surgery.

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with a history of chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be:
questions.solution:
The x ray shows a radiolucent line in the superolateral border of patella. It is very rare for a fracture to occur in this pattern. So, this is not a fracture but Bipartite patella. Similarly, the patient has chronic knee pain which cannot occur in patella fractures.

Bipartite patella is a congenital variation where the patella ossifies as 2 separate bones and later fuses together by synchondrosis. As the synchondrosis will not be visible on x ray, it looks like a fracture line. The diagnosis can be confirmed by taking an x ray of the opposite knee, as this is a bilateral condition.

questions.text: A 35year-old man has had a history of lower back pain and stiffness for 3 months. His ESR and CRP levels are raised. He has mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion is 3 cm. History of the red eye is also there. The most likely diagnosis from amongst the following would be:
questions.solution:
Points in favour of ankylosing spondylosis are

  1. Male gender
  2. Age between 15 to 35 years
  3. Back pain for 3 months
  4. Back stiffness due ankylosis of vertebrae.
  5. Reduced chest expansion which occurs due to the ankylosis of the costovertebral junctions.
  6. Red eye which in due to uveitis. Uveitis is the most common extra articular manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text:
Following an RTA, a patient develops Type Illa compound tibial fracture, arrange the external fixators in terms of stability (lowest to highest)
1. Ilizarov
2. Uniplanar with single rod
3. Uniplanar with double rod
4. Biplanar
questions.solution:
Ilizarov has highest stability as it provides 360 degree stability



Sequence of stability from highest to lowest ilizarov> Uniplanar with double rod> Uniplanar with single rod>biplanar.

questions.text: What is the next step of management in posterior hip joint dislocation?
questions.solution:
Hip joint dislocation are reduced closely first under short general anaesthesia. If it cannot be reduced using close reduction and if associated with acetabular fracture then open reduction is required.

Hip dislocation with or without acetabular or femoral head fracture is an emergency and must be reduced as early as possible. Most of the times close reduction under general anesthesia is possible. Many methods of close reduction have been described like Allis maneuver (Figs. A to D), Biglows maneuver (leverage method, can reduce both anterior and posterior dislocations but not used due to high

Risk of femoral neck fractures),

Stimsons gravity method (Fig. A, B) and Modified East Baltimore lift (Fig. C, D).

Allis maneuver is the most commonly used method for closed reduction of hip dislocation. Once a stable closed reduction is achieved, a temporary skin traction can be given for soft tissue healing and gradually the patient can be mobilized. However, if a closed reduction fails (interposed labrum etc., or incarcinated bone fragments) patient should be urgently posted for an open reduction. Patients with concomitant femoral neck or head fractures also usually require primary open reduction.

questions.text: A patient came with a history of RTA and shaft of femur fracture. Patient was stabilized. After 12 hrs, he developed sudden onset breathlessness, confusion and petechial skin rashes over axilla & chest. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fat embolism: The patient shows signs and symptoms of fat embolism after 12-48 hours of femur fracture or polytrauma. Frequent shifting of the patient without proper splinting of the fracture should be avoided.

This is one of the most serious complications, the essential feature being the occlusion of small vessels by fat globules.

Causes -

  1. Release of free fatty acids (by action of lipases on the neutral fat), which induces a toxic vasculitis, followed by platelet-fibrin thrombosis; and
  2. Actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

Consequences -

  1. Cerebral- In the cerebral type, the patient becomes drowsy, restless and disoriented and gradually goes into a state of coma and
  2. Pulmonary - In the pulmonary type, tachypnoea and tachycardia are the more prominent features.

The other common feature of fat embolism is a petechial rash, usually on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest, or conjunctiva. If untreated, and sometimes despite treatment, the patient develops respiratory failure and dies.

Treatment - Oxygen support, LMW heparin, and steroids

questions.text: Identify the structure marked on the x ray
questions.solution:
Based on the provided X-ray image, the structure marked is: B. Posterior rib

  • The image shows a chest X-ray, likely in a posterior-anterior (PA) projection, where the X-ray beam travels from the posterior (back) to the anterior (front) of the patient.
  • In a PA projection, the posterior ribs are seen superimposed on the anterior ribs, forming a single rib shadow on the X-ray image.
  • The marked structure corresponds to the posterior portion of the rib, which is visible due to the PA projection.

The other options are incorrect:

  • A. Anterior rib: The anterior portion of the rib is not visible as a separate structure in a PA projection.
  • C. Costal cartilage: Costal cartilage is not visible on a plain radiograph, as it is not well-visualized due to its soft tissue density.
  • D. Right descending pulmonary artery: The marked structure is clearly a rib and not a vascular structure like the pulmonary artery.

Therefore, the correct identification of the marked structure on the chest X-ray is B. Posterior rib.

questions.text: A 55 year old lady presented to the OPD with complaints of polyarthralgia for 10 years. She has developed deformities of hands over the last 2 years, Which is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given the information about the 55-year-old lady with a history of polyarthralgia for 10 years and the development of hand deformities over the last 2 years, the most probable diagnosis is:

A.Rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is characterized by chronic inflammation of the joints, leading to pain, swelling, and deformities, particularly in the hands. The progressive nature of her symptoms, including the long duration of polyarthralgia and the specific mention of deformities in the hands, aligns well with the typical presentation of RA.

In RA, the small joints of the hands are commonly affected, and over time, this can lead to characteristic deformities such as ulnar deviation, swan neck deformities, or boutonniere deformities. The bilateral and symmetrical nature of the symptoms is also a hallmark of rheumatoid arthritis.

The other options can be ruled out as follows:

B.Psoriatic arthropathy typically presents with skin lesions and may cause different types of joint deformities, but the history of long-term polyarthralgia without mention of skin symptoms makes it less likely.

C.Osteoarthritis generally presents with joint pain and stiffness but is less likely to cause significant deformities in the same way as RA, especially in the context of a long-standing condition.

D.Reiter's syndrome (now more commonly referred to as reactive arthritis) usually follows an infection and is less likely to present with the chronicity and deformities described.

Therefore, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is A. Rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 12 year old child presented with injury to his right wrist after a fall. His x ray is given below. Identify the type of physeal injury according to the Salter Harris classification.
questions.solution:
Based on the information provided regarding the 12-year-old child with a wrist injury, the type of physeal injury according to the Salter-Harris classification is:

Type 2.

A Salter-Harris Type II fracture is characterized by a fracture that extends through the growth plate (physis) and exits through the metaphysis, often leaving a triangular fragment of the metaphysis known as the Thurston-Holland fragment. This type is the most common among Salter-Harris fractures, accounting for approximately 75% of cases.

In contrast:

Type I involves a fracture that runs directly through the physis without involving the metaphysis.

Type III involves a fracture that goes through the physis and into the epiphysis.

Type IV involves a fracture that traverses through both the metaphysis and the epiphysis, affecting the growth plate.
